General Laws of Massachusetts, Chapter 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to General Laws of Massachusetts, Chapter 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Worcester County and the Defendant resides and conducts business there.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7 21.proposition: As the owner and landlord of 123 Maple Street, Defendant was obligated under G.L. c. 84, § 21 and Massachusetts common law to maintain the sidewalk abutting her property in a reasonably safe condition and to remove or remedy any snow, ice, or other hazards.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..raw_text: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010) (abolishing the natural accumulation rule and requiring property owners to remedy unnatural accumulation of snow and ice).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: (abolishing the natural accumulation rule and requiring property owners to remedy unnatural accumulation of snow and ice).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses and abolishes the natural vs. unnatural accumulation distinction in Massachusetts snow-and-ice premises liability law. It holds that property owners now owe a general duty of reasonable care for all snow and ice hazards, treating them like any other property defect. Thus the case is properly cited for the proposition that the natural accumulation rule is abolished and that owners must remedy dangerous accumulations of snow and ice under a reasonable care standard.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards. … [I]f a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Sweeney v. Ragged Mountain Ski Area, 76.raw_text: Sweeney v. Ragged Mountain Ski Area, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (2009) (property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to visitors).
Sweeney v. Ragged Mountain Ski Area, 76.proposition: (property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to visitors).
Sweeney v. Ragged Mountain Ski Area, 76.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts workers’ compensation limitations case; it concerns when the statute of limitations begins to run under G. L. c. 152, § 41. It does not address premises liability, negligence standards, or duties owed by property owners to visitors. The proposition about property owners owing a duty of reasonable care to visitors is unrelated to the issues decided, so the case does not support that proposition.

Mukome v. Junkins, 59 Mass. App. Ct. 111.raw_text: Mukome v. Junkins, 59 Mass. App. Ct. 1115 (2003) (duty to act reasonably when engaging in snow removal).
Mukome v. Junkins, 59 Mass. App. Ct. 111.proposition: (duty to act reasonably when engaging in snow removal).

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.raw_text: Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) (landlord liability for injuries stemming from defects or hazards on property they control).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: (landlord liability for injuries stemming from defects or hazards on property they control).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses landlord/landowner liability for injuries arising from a dangerous condition on property they control. The SJC reiterates that owners/possessors owe a duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition and, even where a danger is open and obvious, may have a duty to remedy hazards they have created and maintained when they can and should anticipate harm to lawful entrants. The court reverses because the jury were not instructed on this duty to remedy the dangerous trampoline‑pool setup the landlords created and controlled.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’”}

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.raw_text: Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) (reasonable foreseeability as a standard for negligence).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: (reasonable foreseeability as a standard for negligence).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames negligence in terms of what an ordinarily prudent person would foresee and do "in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk." The court’s analysis of whether the defendant should have anticipated (i.e., reasonably foreseen) the plaintiff’s manner of using the elevator is central to its holding. Thus, the case affirms reasonable foreseeability as part of the standard for negligence.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred.”

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., 454 Mass. 37.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., 454 Mass. 37 (2009) (describing causation and damages requirements for a negligence claim).
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., 454 Mass. 37.proposition: (describing causation and damages requirements for a negligence claim).
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., 454 Mass. 37.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recites the elements of a negligence claim, including both causation and damages, and then applies causation principles (including scope of liability/foreseeability) to the facts. It therefore directly describes and applies the causation and damages requirements for negligence, matching the cited proposition.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., 454 Mass. 37.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on his negligence claims, Leavitt must prove that the hospital owed him a duty of reasonable care, that the hospital committed a breach of that duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of duty and the damage. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006), citing J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005); Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990).”

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.raw_text: Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (1994) (reasonableness standard in negligence cases).
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses the standard for a commercial landlord’s negligence liability regarding third‑party criminal acts, framing the duty in terms of reasonable precautions against reasonably foreseeable risks. The court analyzes foreseeability as the central limit on the duty of care and explains that all circumstances are examined in defining the scope of that duty, which is a classic articulation of the reasonableness/foreseeability standard in negligence cases. Thus it is properly cited for a reasonableness standard in negligence, particularly in premises‑liability/third‑party crime contexts.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. … All the circumstances are examined in defining the scope of a duty of care based on the reasonable foreseeability of harm.”

Barry v. Beverly Enterprises, Inc., 418.raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises, Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994) (evidence of landlord’s knowledge of a hazard contributes to liability).
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises, Inc., 418.proposition: (evidence of landlord’s knowledge of a hazard contributes to liability).
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises, Inc., 418.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss landlord (landowner) knowledge as an element of premises liability, but the holding is that there was insufficient evidence of actual or constructive knowledge and thus no liability. The court reverses the earlier trial judge’s view that knowledge could be inferred and instead finds that, without such knowledge, the landlord cannot be liable. Therefore, the case does not stand as authority that evidence of landlord’s knowledge contributes to liability; it is instead an example where lack of such evidence defeats liability.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises, Inc., 418.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, a defendant who did not have a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a hazardous condition — that is, a defendant who had no actual or constructive knowledge of the allegedly hazardous condition so that it could not reasonably remove, or warn the plaintiff of, the danger — cannot be found to have violated its duty of care.… Specifically, we hold that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall.”

Puleio v. Milford Housing Authority, 368.raw_text: Puleio v. Milford Housing Authority, 368 Mass. 283 (1975) (landlord’s duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition).
Puleio v. Milford Housing Authority, 368.proposition: (landlord’s duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition).
Puleio v. Milford Housing Authority, 368.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about grand jury proceedings and alleged use of false testimony in securing an indictment. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, premises liability, or any discussion of a landlord’s duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition. The proposition appears to be mismatched to the cited case.
Puleio v. Milford Housing Authority, 368.relevant_excerpt: No excerpt in this opinion discusses landlord duties, premises maintenance, or reasonably safe conditions; the entire text concerns criminal procedure, grand jury testimony, and evidentiary issues in a kidnapping and rape prosecution.
